         “Can it wait Robbie? I’m rather tired.”
         “Um, no I think I should prepare for this first. You see, I’ve sort of let myself go and have gained some weight since you’ve been gone these months.”
         “Robbie, can we please talk about this when I get home? If you’ve put on some weight, fine, just get a trainer. I’ll talk more when I get there.” The line went dead.
         “Well, I’m dead.”
         “Oh? Everything alright?”
         “Yeah. And you might want to make a larger serving. That was Italia and she’ll be home soon and is hungry.”
         “Ah. Gotcha. I hope you don’t mind if I’m not here when she gets home then? I don’t want to risk being collateral damage if things go wrong. And I’ll warn Taylor too so he can get his stuff packed up.”
         “I’ll warn Taylor. You focus on getting that food ready so Italia won’t have an extra reason to target you.”
         “Sounds good, but just so you know, Taylor will likely want to stay. I think he views you as his personal project right now and he can get really territorial.”
         “I’ll keep that in mind.” Robbie headed upstairs, Robert still swinging his rattle around in his arms. “Hey, Taylor, you might want to call it a day.”
         “What? I just got unpacked and your clothes are still in need of being let out after weeks off!”
         “I just got off the phone with Italia. She’s on her way home and I don’t want you getting caught in her crosshairs if anything goes wrong.”
         Taylor straightened up, his brow furrowing. All the light in the room seemed to fade into the corners. “And just what would she do? You just put me in my place about it being your body, not mine. Are you going to let her control you? As for me, I’m just altering your clothes. If she targets me for ANYTHING, she has another thing coming!”
         “Taylor! No you will not! Because you won’t be here! Pack up for the day! I’ll give you a call when you can come back, AND YOU WILL COME BACK, but you’re not to be here when she gets here or you WON’T be coming back! Malcolm is trying to finish the meals for the day in the next hour so have all your stuff in his car before then! Do I make myself clear?”
         The light seemed to return to most of the room but Taylor’s face remained dark as he started throwing his gear back into his cases.
         Robbie headed back to the kitchen.
         “Need any help?” He asked as he placed Robert in his play pen.
         “Not really. Almost done as it is. Is Taylor leaving or did he back you into a corner?”
         “He didn’t get the chance. He either goes with you or he doesn’t come back.”
         Malcolm’s eyebrow rose above his glasses. “Well, that will probably bite you in the ass, but then again, maybe not. It will depend on how it goes with Italia.”
         The timer dinged. Malcolm grabbed an oven mitt and pulled out an extra-large quiche.
         “Okay. Your food is ready. I put some hamburger patties in the fridge for you to cook later as well as a fruit salad. Thank God I didn’t go for something like fettucine Alfredo. I might be unemployed if I’d made that.”
         “I wouldn’t let her fire you. We’re equal in this relationship. You’ll still have a job here, even if she hates you. Though if that’s the case, I’ll put in a good word with some of the local restaurants to get you a good job.”
         “Thanks Robbie, I mean Mr. Amell. I’m going to have to get used to that again. Miss Italia was always very strict about that.”
         “Yeah, I’ll try to talk to her about that too, but probably not right now. Now, you better get going. She’ll be here any minute.”
         “You ready Taylor?” Malcolm shouted upstairs.
         “Yeah, yeah. I’m coming. I still think we should stay.”
         “You ever watch those documentaries about injured or cornered animals?”
         Taylor raised an eyebrow and snarled.
         “Like that, yeah, except she’s the cornered animal and she will fight to the death if she feels cornered. This is better handled by myself.”
         “I’m not going to argue. She’s your wife. You know her, I don’t.” He dragged his sewing kit out.
         “He’ll calm down. Give us a call when it’s safe to return.”
         “I will. Sorry this had to happen right when you got back to work.”
         “Not your fault. See you later.” Malcolm joined Taylor in the car and drove off.
         Robbie joined Robert back in the kitchen. The sweet smell of the fruit filled the air even over the smell of the freshly baked quiche. While waiting for Italia to arrive, he went around cleaning up the messes that Malcolm hadn’t been able to clean. He’d barely gotten the center island cleaned when the front door opened.
         “Robbie! I’m home!” He heard Italia yell from the entryway.
         He drew in a deep breath. “We’re in the kitchen!” He called back.
         “Great! I hope Malcolm made something good! I’m starving and right now I really don’t care….” Her jaw dropped as she entered the kitchen and saw Robbie’s new build. “Robbie, honey, I know you said you’d gained some weight, but your fat!”
         “I know. I tried to tell you on the phone but you hung up on me.”
         “You gained all that weight in the time I was gone? You look…”
11412211535314325322521.title: Italia's surprise return

114122115353143253225213.content:
Italia barely talked to Robbie for the next few weeks. Every time she looked at him, her eyes were hard. So Robbie took the opportunity to try to get her to enjoy his new build as much as he had before she got home. It didn’t go smoothly in the bedroom as she rolled away every time he tried to snuggle. At meals, she would try to send Malcolm away whenever he tried to give Robbie a second helping only for Robbie to take it right there anyways. She even tried to take Robert to her mother’s to force him to lose weight which she quickly lost the battle when Robert cried incessantly for two days for him. Kevin was also torn between follow Italia’s orders to increase his workouts, which he agreed with wholeheartedly, and keeping the things the same as Robbie was demanding on threat of cancelling his gym membership and bad reviews for not helping the client on their goals so Robbie cut him a tiny bit of slack and agreed to increase resistance training by one session a week.
         It was that compromise that led to Italia lightening up. With the increased calories and workout, Robbie’s gut firmed up a bit around the top and sides, an inch of flab still hanging on the bottom, but the rest of his muscles also increased. His former definition hadn’t come back and Italia still wouldn’t touch him, but with his shifting from flabby fat guy to the start of a power lifter build, conversation started back up. Mostly she still wanted him to lose, to go back to the way things were but he let her know that boat had sailed.
         After being home almost two months, Robbie’s weight had stabilized at 250 pounds. After being at that weight for a week, Robbie could tell Italia thought she was winning the battle with his bulge. With the arguing that had gone one since she’d gotten home, he hadn’t had a chance to cook her anything with his new skills. Tired of looking at him again, she took Robert to the mall for the day to hang out with her girlfriends, gossip and complain about her new fat and lazy husband. He took the chance to cook up all her favorites, only having Malcolm help with the prep then leave. Their neighbor was even going to take Robert for the evening to have a play date with their kids so he could make it a real date.
         When Italia arrived home that night, Robbie had rose petals spread all over the floor creating a path through the house.

“Follow the petals.”

         Candles lit the house and illuminated a black backless dress with a diamond sash around the waist and neck.

“Leave Robert in the crib and feel free to spruce up however you feel. Follow the petals down to your special evening. Everything has been arranged tonight!”

         Getting dressed, she did as was told and left Robert in his crib. The rose petals leading to the back stairs changed from red to white to guide her down to a rose, lily, and lilac filled dining room. The only lights came from the dozens of candles scattered around. The dining room table had been removed in place of table for two with candelabras. A cart was parked next to the table loaded with all of Italia’s favorite dishes.
         “Your seat Mademoiselle?” Robbie pulled out a chair for her. Even through the distaste she had shown him the past few weeks, she had to take a second glance at the tux that was tailored to show off his new size. In the candle light, his gut may have looked slightly larger, but his arms and shoulders looked firmer than ever and his slicked back hair slimmed his face a bit.
         Not sure what to say, Italia settled into the chair which he gently slid under her as she sat down. Evening when they were dating, he hadn’t done anything like this. She had no clue how to react but for the first time since getting home, she didn’t care about his looks.
         “For the first course, we have a refreshing summer strawberry salad.”
         “Malcolm must have taken all day preparing all this.” Italia stated as he placed a helping of the salad on the small top plates.
         “It did, but it wasn’t Malcolm. He only helped prep. I did all the cooking.”
         Italia gaped at him. “I didn’t know you could cook.”
         “It was supposed to be a surprise for you when you got home but you took one look at me and never gave me a chance to really explain anything. To be honest, if it weren’t for learning to cook, I wouldn’t have gained any weight, but I wanted to do something special for you.”
         Italia looked down at the strawberry she had started pushing around on her plate as he spoke.
         “I get it. We’re both used to being around really fit people. We likely never would have even met had we not both had our looks, but frankly, this time off has made me enjoy raising Robert. I’ve barely even cared about not working since we have plenty of money and even if I keep the weight, I’d rather that to take better care of our son then go back to work, being miserable in the process, and missing our son growing up, or worse, both of us being to busy to raise him or see any of his big moments.”
         He waited for her to say something.
         “You’re right.” She finally said. “Our son comes first. And we should be here for him. I don’t like or agree with your weight gain but it is up to you and as long as it doesn’t interfere with raising him properly, I won’t stop you from stopping acting or push you to lose, but I will insist you don’t gain anymore. Work more with Kevin.”
         “I’ll continue working with Kevin, I decided that months ago, but I’m not going to actively work to lose. If I lose, I lose. If I gain, I gain. And think of it this way, if I’m not worried about my weight, I can cook meals like this whenever you want. You don’t have indulge, just try to understand that I do. And give me a chance tonight. You might find I’m all the better at snuggling!” He winked at her, eliciting a blush in spite of her reluctance. “So will you do me that favor? Just give me a chance.”
         Italia took another bite of her salad. “Okay. I’ll give this a shot. For Robert!”
         Robert grinned. “Are you ready for the second course? There are five total. Don’t worry. They’re all your favorites made just the way you like, so other than the chocolate cannolis for dessert, they aren’t heavy.”
         She grinned again as he scooped several scallops with sauce onto a small sauce plate, switching it out with her salad plate.
         “Did you really make all this?”
         “Yeah. All of it. Malcolm only helped prep everything.”
         The appetizer and soup went by silently, only some soft instrumental music playing.
         “Shouldn’t we go check on Robert?” Italia asked as Robbie slid a wooden plank covered with rice pilaf and a salmon steak in front of her.
         “He’s next door. I asked Nathan and Laura to watch him tonight. I had them come get him about half an hour after you got home. They’ll bring him back in the morning. I wanted tonight to just be the two of us so we could really talk things over. Sorry. I should have told you that sooner.”
         “Yes, you should have.”
         They chatted about different things from Taylor’s alterations to the parties that Robbie still wanted to go to if for no other reason than his new friends to everything Italia did for the new movie. Dessert came about with only a couple of cannolis for Italia and ten for him. Italia didn’t try to hide her disapproval but didn’t say anything. With everything gone, Robbie loaded all the dishes onto the cart and pushed it back into the kitchen.
         “If you’ll follow me, Madam, the night is not over.”
         He held out his hand to help her up. He led her down a path of pink rose petals to the back yard where a gazebo had been set up over the patio with an orchestra to the side.
         "May I have this dance?" Robbie held out his hand.
         Heading into the middle, the orchestra played a waltz. Soft strobe lights shone onto a temporary chandelier. With the first dance done, a more upbeat tango started.
         Italia hesitated. "Are you up for this?"
         "I'm fine." He pulled her close and moved into a tango far to graceful for someone his size. "I may have gotten fat, but I haven't let myself go." He informed her as she went into a dip. The orchestra played as the couple danced the night away.
         Shortly before midnight, the orchestra packed up their strings but it wasn't for another hour that the dancers finally finished. Even with her former reluctance, the night ended with heavy breathing for both of the couple and a new admiration for Robbie's new heft.

1141221153531432532252132.content:
Robbie had the alarm preset before they had even started the date last night and the moment it went off, he was reaching for it so that Italia wouldn’t be disturbed. She rolled over as he got up. It was the first night since she’d got back that were actually together and not just sleeping in the same bed. He froze. She moaned in her sleep but didn’t wake up.
         Getting dressed, he headed to the kitchen to whip up some buckwheat pancakes. He never cared for the taste, even less so since he stopped monitoring what he ate, but this wasn’t for him. Pancakes made, fresh bananas sliced on them, a fruit and yogurt parfait layered in a tall cup to show off its layers, a couple slices of turkey bacon cooked just short of becoming crispy, orange juice poured, small decanter of syrup and vial of sunflowers on a tray, he carried it up.
         He waited until he heard her shut off her alarm, then knocked gently and pushed the door open.
         “Breakfast!” he whispered loudly. Placing the tray on the stand beside the bed, he pulled open the curtains some to let in the early morning light.
         “What’s this? I thought the date was last night?”
         “Who said it had to be over? Or that you can’t have two back to back?” He gave her a peck on the cheek and moved the tray across her lap.
         “I have to admit, I’m surprised how good you are at cooking. Everything last night was delicious.”
         “You can say that again.” He winked at her eliciting a blush.
         “That…” she monitored her words carefully, “was surprising as well.”
         “I’m still the same me you knew and fell in love with several years ago, there’s just more to love.”
         “And I could tell that last night. You didn’t have any trouble moving around. In fact, that was the best you’ve ever done, and that’s saying something!” It was Robbie’s turn to blush.
         “So is everything fine? You don’t have to brag about my weight or anything, but can we at least agree this isn’t something to tear ourselves apart over?”
         She took a bite of the pancake. “Hmmm! It practically melts!”
         Robbie took the fork from her and held a piece up for her. She hesitated then took the bite. “I guess not. It’ll take some getting used to, but if you promise not to overboard on the rich dishes, than I guess I can take it.” She accepted another bite of pancakes.
         “I’ll be sure to monitor what I make so it’s not any harder for you to keep your figure. I’m going to make meals I enjoy too, but I’ll keep those for when you’re not home. That a good compromise?”
         “Okay. Where’d you learn to cook anyways? Did Malcolm teach you?”
         “In part. He helped supplement the cooking classes I started taking several months ago.”
         They continued chatting as he fed her the rest of her meal. On occasion Robbie would nuzzle Italia’s neck, getting some giggles from her. They ended up in bed until noon when Robbie got up.
         “I’ll leave you to get dressed. I’m supposed to pick up Robert at 1.”
         “You have any more surprises planned?”
         “Maybe. But you’ll have to wait and see. I’ll be back in a few minutes.”
         He left to get Robert while she got up. Although he didn’t have anything planned for that night, he did his best to make an enjoyable dinner for the three of them. Italia got a kick out him wearing most of Robert’s mac and cheese.
         Watching a movie that night, Italia opted to sit next to him, allowing him to wrap his arm around her. It was like they were dating all over again. Maybe this was a new start to their relationship?

11412211535314325322521321.content:
Robbie and Italia continued their renewed courtship for a couple weeks until another event took up their attention: Robert’s first birthday!
         Robbie took the lead in planning while Italia did most of the shopping. All the families from the daycare they sometimes frequented were invited as well as Laura and Nathan, some other neighbors with kids, Stephen’s family and Taylor. Italia wanted to object to Taylor’s being there, not knowing him that well, but all her arguments fell flat as Robert loved him.
         Party packs were put together with streamers and blowers for the adults and toys for the kids. Robbie made a marble cake and a second smaller vanilla cake for those with food allergies, both which were decorated by Malcolm. Veggie platers, cheese and cracker trays, and cookie plates were lined on a table for everyone. A separate table was set up for Robert’s presents to be put on. Streamers were draped around the entryway through to the backyard patio. Uninflated balloons and a helium tank sat near a pile of kid’s games.
         Everything was set up an hour before the first guest was set to arrive. Except Italia who was pacing in their bedroom.
         Robbie gently knocked. “Everything alright?”
         She kept pacing.
         “Hey, honey, talk to me. Everything’s all set. It’s going to be fine and even if things don’t, well it’s only Robert’s first birthday. It’s not like he’ll remember it.”
         Italia stopped, glaring at him. “You really think I’m worried about the party? I couldn’t care less about that! But this is the first time anyone’s seen us together since this,” she gestured at his gut, “I’ve told some friends but no one actually believed me! They are never going to let this go! I mean, has your cousin even seen you?”
         “No. And frankly, I don’t care what others say at this point and I’m surprised you are either. We’ve talked about this and this is my choice as long as I can still take care of Robert.”
         “You don’t care? These are our friends and family you’re talking about! How can you not care?!”
         “Italia, if things start going rough, just let me know. Trust me, when Taylor first started fixing my clothes, he was really pushing me to actively gain and actually tried to strong arm me into gaining weight and Kevin also tried to shame me into becoming a fitness addict again, but frankly, I’m actually rather happy with who I am now, and like with those two, if anyone tries to give either of us a hard time, I’ll shut them down. It’s none of their business anyways. I won’t let them attack you over my choices. Okay?” She tried to look away but he gently used a finger to direct her gaze back to him. “Okay?”
         She nodded.
         “Good. Then let’s get downstairs before…” The doorbell rang. “Exactly that happens.” He chuckled, leading her out of the room.
         “Hey, Cous. Sorry we’re earllll….. What the hell happened to you?!” Stephen gawked at Robbie.
         “Oh, this? I’ve just taken a break and maybe indulged myself some.”
         “A little? Dude! You’re a butterball!”
         “Eh. I’m also loving spending time with my son and not having to monitor every calorie I eat or slaving away in the gym.” Robbie headed back inside leaving Stephen and his wife and daughter to follow behind.
         Robbie saw Stephen start to whisper something to Italia. As quietly as he could, he snuck around behind the group. Italia spotted him as he got behind them.
         “The presents go over there.” She stated, ending the whispered conversation.
         Stephen took the present from his daughter and placed it on the empty table.
         More people arrived, trickling in a few here and there until most of the people had shown up. The younger toddlers were placed in a play pen while some of the older kids went out to the butterfly tent. Taylor was one of the last to arrive but he had brought a plus one, Margie.
         Robbie’s grin turned into a grimace. Italia and a couple neighbors had met Taylor but even Italia had only heard about the growth parties. No one else had met one. They were about to. At least it was Margie, the kindest person he knew.
         Italia greeted them before Robbie could get over, accepting Margie’s gift. He couldn’t hear what was said, but he was relieved when she pointed to him and Italia glanced over a smile on her face, though being an actress, he didn’t know if it was real.
         “She seems nice.” Italia commented as she put the newest presents on the table. “Where’d you meet her? I haven’t seen her before.”
         “She’s from those parties I told you about. But I had no idea she was coming. She’s never even met Robert.”
         “That’s what she told me too. If you’re having an affair, just tell me now because if not, you two have a stupid cover story.”
         “We’re not having an affair! She’s just a friend!”
         Italia raised an eyebrow. She left to mingle with the guests.
         Robbie kept an eye on Italia as she conversed with her friends. A few times she sent a panicked look over his way but always sent him away before he could get there.
         After half an hour, Malcolm called everyone together for the cake. Robert giggled as everyone sang “Happy Birthday” though it was Robbie who blew out the single candle to the crowd’s cheers. Slices of cake were handed out and eaten as Italia unwrapped Robert’s gifts. Most were actually for her and Robbie and the ones actually for Robert were opened and handed to him. He loved most the toys though a stegosaurus plushy had him screaming when Italia squeaked it when giving it to him.
         Presents unwrapped, cakes eaten, and balloons all blown up, the party gradually died down. Robbie was surprised to see Italia once again chatting with Margie, the two of them laughing at something.
         “Hey, can we talk?” Stephen asked through his teeth.
         “If it’s about my weight and everything, no. I know you won’t understand, but I’m actually happy. I still have a trainer          I’m working with, but I’m not planning on restricting myself either. Look Stephen, I’m not asking or looking for your approval, but I am asking that you back off for now. You see me having trouble walking ten feet or if I get diabetes and you see me continually shoving in candy bars or if Robert starts getting neglected, then you can butt in and stop me, but until then, butt out.” Robbie left Stephen standing there.
         “Well?” Robbie asked when everyone finally left with the exceptions of Malcolm, Taylor and Margie who started straightening up.
         “Well what?” Italia asked.
         “Did anyone give you a hard time over my weight?”
         “Honestly, a lot of people are really upset and worried about you. I didn’t really know how to handle it, but I’ll likely hear more later, otherwise, most people dropped it when the subject was changed. Or when that friend of yours butted in. She was really nice and often was really good at redirecting the conversations. I know you want to spend more time raising Robert, but I asked if she’d look after him if you ever wanted a break. I mean, you seem to know and trust her.” She raised an eyebrow.
         “I do trust her. It was her that helped me actually get comfy with who I am now. I wouldn’t mind her watching Robert on occasion. Who knows, maybe that means more alone time for us?” Wrapping his arms around her waist.
         “Have your alone time when alone!” Taylor chuckled as he loaded wrapping paper into a trash bag.
         Italia chuckled. “I think we may need to take her up on that.”

“You ready?” Robbie yelled up to Italia.
         “Almost!”
         “You better hurry.” Margie told him. “Ohhh! I miss having kids around!” She chuckled, tickling Robert.
         “I’m waiting on her!” Robbie stated, pacing the foyer. He pulled on his shirt again but all it did was cause the buttons to strain a little more over his gut. In the couple months since Robert’s birthday, he’d put on another 15 pounds and an inch to his waist and it showed in the tightness of his clothes. Unfortunately, Malcolm and Taylor had to go out of town for Taylor’s sister’s wedding for a month so Robbie’s clothes had not grown with him like usual.
         “I’m ready!” Italia slowly modeled her way down the stairs, her black, ankle length dress flowing around her legs as she descended.
         “I used to have that figure.” Margie fluffed her own curly hair. Italia flashed a smile at her.
         “I’m sure you did.”
         “Now, you two need to get going or you’re going to be late!” She pushed past Robbie to open the door for them.
         “Okay, okay. We’re going!” Robbie guided Italia to their BMW, arm around her waist.
         The cooking studio was packed that night as everyone in the class had brought a friend or their family in order to try their specialty dishes.
         “Thank you for joining us in this final class!” The instructor called from his table in front of everyone. “Tonight is a special night as the chefs here will not be assigned a dish and have instead chosen a dish of their own to make. This dish will consist of a main course and two sides. Two hours will be provided to make everyone who was invited a meal. They selected their meals last week and the ingredients have been provided for the proper number of people. There will only be one chance to get this right, people, so don’t mess up! Time begins now!” A clock on the wall started counting down.
         Several kids pulled out games, a few adults pulled out books. One lady with an infant stepped out.
         All the chefs started preparing their dishes. Robbie filled several pots of water and placed them on high heat, threw some wild rice with some chicken bouillon and herbs in to cook, grabbed some potatoes and peeled them. With the sides now cooking, he prepared the lobster, getting it ready to boil.
         Once the potatoes were ready to mash, he placed the lobsters in the final pot to boil. As the main dish was prepping, he mashed the potatoes, adding plenty of butter, salt, cheese, herbs and scallions. He sampled the rice, adding more herbs to season it. The potatoes ready, he placed them under heating lamp on the spare station behind him and Angelina. The rice and lobsters finished at the same time. Slicing open the lobsters, he squeezed fresh lemons on it and melted some butter over some herbs to dip the meat in.
         Plating everything, he signaled for the instructor to come check.
         “Let’s see.” He took a sample of everything, just enough to taste but not enough to mess with the display. “The rice and potatoes are perfectly balanced and seasoned though the lobster is on the verge of being overcooked. You pulled it out just in time but the meat is just a tiny bit rubbery already. A minute longer and I would not have passed this. Your wife is the final judge, not me, so your passing is up to her. Enjoy.” He waved Robbie off.
         Robbie pulled both plates onto a tray which he single handedly carried over to the table where Italia was waiting.
         “It looks delicious.” She stated as he set one of the plates in front of her.
         “And although it’s not the most romantic date,” Robbie reached under the warming table to pull out a small vase with a single purple and white orchid in it. The vase was placed in the center of the table.
         The two ate in relative silence so Italia could focus on appraising the food.
         As she finished her meal, Italia took out a check list the instructor had provide for each friend or family member could use to judge the food. There were several sections she filled out before calling the instructor over. Most of the people in the class were already finished so he finished with the current student and came over.
         “Let’s see.” He read over her sheet. “Lobster was adequate. Seasoning was made up for the slight chewiness. A few grains of rice were undercooked but only a small number. The potatoes were to rich but were otherwise good. Overall rating, 8 out of 10.” He placed the sheet on the table. “Lobster is a difficult dish to properly cook as is wild rice, so it not being perfect is no surprise but overall, you have done very well and I hereby award you with this certificate of completion and an invitation to attend a more advanced cooking class if you’d like, which I don’t think you’ll actually need, but there is a spot if you’d like it.” He placed a sheet on the table with a second small slip attached and walked off.
         “I was afraid it was possibly overcooked. Did you enjoy it?”
         “It was great.”
         “Just great? You don’t sound very enthusiastic.”
         “No, no. It was delicious. It’s just a little bit much. And the potatoes were…” She hissed through her teeth.
         “I know. I thought that would be a bit much, but once in while won’t hurt. I’m not planning on making a habit of dinners like that. This is a special occasion, that’s all.”
         “All right. Now we should get home. I have to get up tomorrow. Michael has an audition lined up for tomorrow.”
         “And you don’t like carbs before big filming or auditions. I’m sorry. But other than that, did you like it?”
         She nodded. "You passes, didn't you?"
         Robbie collected his awards and headed out behind, sighing.

1141221153531432532252132123.content:
Robbie got to the party a little late. He’d had a sheet cake in the oven that he had to wait to cool to put the frosting on. Knocking, he let himself in, the cake barely balanced on one arm.
“You made it! I was beginning to wonder!” Margie clapped as he brought the cake to an open area on the dessert table.
“Yeah. Cake came out of the oven later than I wanted.”
“Well, you made it. That’s what matters. I’ll go grab a knife for that cake.”
“Thanks Margie.” He glanced around at the party goers. Lucas and Tristan were in their usual spots on the couch. With the weather growing colder, Mark and his gang had taken over the kitchen a couple weeks back but even with the massive muscles and boulder guts, not a single man there stood in Margie’s way, with or without a knife in her hand. Taylor and the buffet group, as Robbie had dubbed them, were in the back room, probably playing poker. Several people were gathered around the buffet table but one in particular caught his eye.
At the end of the table, Andy was pointing out various people to a short guy that was almost as wide as he was tall. He wasn’t fat wide like Lucas or Tristan, no, he had muscles that rivaled Mark’s but without the gut on him. The guy’s hair was slightly spiked to match his chiseled facial features. The chilled temps outside didn’t seem to faze this guy if his shorts and tank top were any indication. His green eyes carefully observed everyone that Andy pointed out to him.
“Who’s the new guy?” Robbie asked as Margie returned and started cutting the cake.
“Oh, him? A friend of Andy’s I guess. I haven’t had a chance to meet him yet but they arrived together. Here you go.” She handed Robbie the first slice of the cake.
Margie plated a second piece for him to take over. He hadn’t really gotten to know Andy that well over the weeks, he didn’t seem to be a very talkative guy, but he knew that he always enjoyed watching others eat though he himself only ate small portions, liking to keep his runner’s build.
“You want a slice?” Robbie held out a slice of the cake to the bodybuilder.
“Thanks. Looks good. I haven’t eaten real food in a while.”
“Why’s that?”
“I just did a competition. Had to cut. Now that that’s over, I’m back. Wow. This is some great cake. You make this yourself?”
“Yeah. Thanks. I’m Robbie.”
“I’ve heard about you from Martha. You’re smaller than she described.”
“Oh, um…” Robbie glanced down at his newly fitted long sleeve shirt. It was the first of his winter shirts Taylor had prepped for him. It had been lengthened several inches so his gut was warm and covered once again.
“Hey, don’t worry about it. Everyone here is different. I’m Osmond.”
“You want another slice?” Robbie gestured at Osmond’s empty plate.
“Nah. I don’t like to dirty bulk. Why don’t I get you another slice instead?” He grabbed Robbie’s plate and topped it with a slice that filled most of the plate before Robbie could stop him. “Here you go.”
“Um, thanks. I wasn’t planning on having another slice right now.”
“Sorry. I get overeager at these parties sometimes, trying to eat vicariously. Hope I don’t upset you if I sometimes push food on you. It just means I really want some more myself.” He chuckled. “That, and it means I think you have a good starter build.”
“Leave him alone Osmond. He’s not a serious gainer.” Andy scowled.
“I know that Andy. Sheesh. Why are you such a party pooper?”
“I’m surprised you aren’t in the kitchen with the other big guys.” Robbie started on his second slice of cake.
“Those meatheads? Don’t make me laugh. They just flex and gut bump. I like to talk to people and those gorillas aren’t good for conversation.”
“Funny to hear you of all people call others “meathead”. How big are you anyways?”
“Hey, just because I like being big doesn’t mean it’s all I’m about. As for size,” he started flexing as he rattled off his measurements. Robbie’s eyes widened as he flexed his bowling ball biceps, bounced his pecs that rivaled Robbie’s own moobs, and shook thighs that were only different in their firmness from his own.
“Damn! You weigh as much as I do!” Robbie whistled.
“Seriously? We weigh the same? You’re right, DAMN! You look like you should outweigh me by a lot! Need to work on that! Mind if I get you another plate?” He waited for Robbie to respond this time.
“Thanks for the offer, but like Andy said, I’m not a serious gainer. I’m just trying to enjoy what I eat, that’s all, and if I continue putting on weight, fine, if I don’t, also fine, but I really don’t want to be pushed. I’ve gone over this with Taylor, Malcolm, my wife and my personal trainer and I will send Margie over if you push me.”
Osmond held up his hands. “Alright, alright. I’ve seen Margie get upset, it’s not pretty and I would not want her as an enemy. But honestly, you seem like a nice guy and I wouldn’t mind getting a bite to eat with you sometimes. Nothing funny and no pressure!” He added quickly as Robbie raised an eyebrow.
“Well, maybe. How long you been bodybuilder?”
“About 12 years.”
“Well, you’ve definitely made progress! How’d you do at your contest?”
“Fourth. Would have been third but my abs are asymmetrical.” He lifted up his shirt to reveal a six pack that would have put Robbie’s own old abs to shame had the right side not been a half an ab higher than the left.
“I’m 275 now and people were bigger than you?”
“Bigger? No. I was the biggest. They were just better conditioned. And it didn’t help that I got stuck attempting some splits while on stage.”
Robbie winced. “What is it you do?”
“I’m an architect. What about you? I’d heard you’re taking some time off from acting?”
“To raise my son. You have a family?”
“Nah. Not yet. I have a girlfriend, but I doubt it’s going to last much longer between us.”
“That stinks.”
“Eh. I met her at my nephew’s baseball game, so not entirely surprised.”
“Why would that be a sign it wouldn’t work out?”
“She was the opposing team’s assistant coach.”
“What grade is your nephew in?”
“Freshman in high school.”
“That explains it.”
“Yep. She understood the fitness aspect of bodybuilding, which is where we started talking, but when it came to the competition and just getting as big as possible, that’s where she’s been ragging on me non-stop for the past couple weeks. The contest’s over but she wants me to cut back a little and that is not happening.”
“Italia still wants me to cut back too. She didn’t like that I was around 225 when she got home from her latest movie. She seemed to have been getting used to my new weight even though I’ve gotten bigger since then, but I’m not sure.”
“Being bigger isn’t for everyone. I’ve tried to pick up women at clubs, the library, even gyms, who said I was gross because of how big I am.”
“I’ve been getting looks like that when I go out recently too. It makes me self-conscious.”
“It shouldn’t. That build really suits you.”
“Thanks, I guess.”

154131.content:
Hemsworth awoke with a groan as light streamed in through his bedroom window and his eyes fought to open. Moving his head slowly to the side he gave a petulant grunt as the light hit his face and he instinctively turned away from it, pushing himself up and raising an arm as if it were enough to disintegrate the sun. Swinging his legs over the side of the bed, he rubbed his eyes with his fingers and frowned into his palms. He never forgot to close the blinds in his bedroom, but then yesterday was hardly a typical day. It was the wrap up day on his last film, or films, and he had spent the best part of half a year filming and countless hours before and during working on his physique. He had done some of his best work on those films and some of the suggestions he had pushed for had been adapted into his character, which made him proud - but then why was his mind pulled back to the events of last night?

Slowly rising to his feet, Hemsworth ran a hand down his chin in thought as his eyes began to adjust to the light and he started to see more clearly. He was with the other Chris after everyone else bailed, they both ordered one of the biggest steaks on the menu and then they went home. Hemsworth grunted again, shaking his head as if to clear it or dislodge a memory. There was no way that that was right. He vaguely remembered ordering the steak but he didn't really remember the menu or choosing it. It almost felt as though someone else had suggested it to him, there wasn't anyone else that they really spoke to and Evans had never recommended any food to him before and they barely even spoke that night. That was weird too. Going out had never been about the food before, it was always about letting off some steam and relaxing. They may never have been all that loud, but they never sat in near silence eating before but that's what he remembered. He wasn't even sure if the two had said goodbye to each other, he certainly didn't remember it and what time did they leave? It felt like it must have been late as he still felt so tired, yet if all they had was a steak they couldn't have been there for more than an hour. Plus, who paid? The two must have gotten into a tug of war over paying, not that he remembered that either but...

If there was a receipt then it would have itemized everything that they bought and it would probably have the time that it was printed off on there too! Hemsworth strode over to the end table where his jeans had been slung and began to rifle through the pockets. As he searched for his wallet, he noticed that it had fallen onto the floor but his hand had already hit his keys as well as a piece of paper, so he lazily grabbed them and yanked them gracelessly out. He leaned over and placed the keys on the table before turning his attention to what turned out to be a napkin, rather than a piece of paper. He vaguely remembered the two girls and after unfolding the napkin found the phone number that he recalled one of them writing down. What he didn't remember was the small piece of card that fell out onto the floor. He squinted at it, but it was a little difficult to make out, so as lazy as he was feeling he was forced to bend down to pick it up. Squatting down felt like an effort and he felt so sluggish and heavy that he almost toppled forward, but he steadied himself and turned his attention to the card.

It was a gaudy gold and red color and it seemed to have some kind of characters or symbols on it, but he couldn't quite make out exactly what it said, if it it said anything legible at all and it hurt his eyes to try. The pressure in his thighs began to grow, so he pushed himself back up, feeling the effort of straightening up again even more keenly than lowering himself down. There was even something about himself that felt off, or was it his house? It wasn't so much that he felt like there were missing pieces to the puzzle, it was more like there were several puzzles on the go and he didn't know which pieces went with which vista.

So what were his options? Hemsworth looked down at the napkin and card in his hands. He didn't remember those girls being around after they put that napkin in his pocket, but then he didn't really remember the rest of the night so it was possible that he saw them again or that they might have some kind of insight about what was going on. He had no idea what the card meant, if the girls snuck it into his pocket wrapped in the napkin or if someone else gave it to him, but he could probably find out more about it online if he wanted to. Perhaps an image search or he could get someone to look into it for him. It could be totally mundane, but he felt weird looking at it, as if it held some kind of deeper meaning...

Practically speaking, he could drop by to the restaurant and ask the staff or perhaps the host what was going on that night in a subtle, roundabout kind of way of course. If anyone knew exactly what was going on it should be the person who was serving their table that night, who was... he couldn't even remember anything about them. But someone would be able to and they would be the most likely to have all the answers to the most pressing questions. The only other person who might know would be Evans. As he didn't remember Evans speak, maybe that meant that he had spent that time listening and observing? At the very least Evans might be able to confirm that he remembers just as little as he does, not that he was sure that the concept of that was more or less comforting. The only other option was to stay at home and to explore other avenues. Not that things felt normal there either, but perhaps the answer was staring him in the face. Or maybe he was the problem, not his home or the previous night. He still felt a bit off, like when a last minute script change came down and he had to deviate from what he had learned; it felt as if someone how edited the script of his life and done a pretty sloppy job of it, but he would find out what happened last night. The only immediate question that he had the power to answer was, how?

1541313.content:
Hemsworth decided that the most obvious choice was to return to the restaurant and see if anyone there could shed any light on what happened last night. The napkin with the girls number and that gaudy card seemed a bit insubstantial and more of a plan B and he didn't want to have to call Evans and worry him if he was just overreacting. When a crime is committed, the police talk to any eyewitnesses first for a good reason, so it made sense for him to see if anyone knew or saw anything weird last night. Hemsworth frowned as he walked toward his wardrobe, pushing gently on the door and watching it glide effortlessly open. He was a bit worried that his mind went straight to the idea of the police and crime, hopefully it wasn't his subconscious trying to tell him something, or warning him, about what happened. Hemsworth picked out a fresh pair of jeans that were identical to the ones that he wore the previous evening and a baby blue t-shirt and lay them on the bed. It was much more likely that last night was just an anomaly, that all of the stress from his six months of hard work came out in a weird way but he had come to learn to trust his instincts and he had a sinking feeling. He would be happy to be proved wrong, but if something did happen and he ended up appearing on the front page of some cheap tabloid on the shelves of a supermarket, he wanted to know if the far-fetched headline had even an ounce of truth about it.

After taking a shower, Hemsworth got changed and scooped up his keys, wallet and the items from his 'evidence locker' - the napkin and red and gold card and began to head down the stairs. He felt a lot less sluggish and more together after the shower and more positive about deciding to go back to the restaurant. He vaguely remembered The Ranch taking lunch time bookings and as it was approaching midday, he was pretty confident that he could get there and potentially get some answers pretty smoothly. As he neared the bottom of the stairs and felt himself move in his clothes, Hemsworth remembered that the jeans were identical to the ones that he wore last night in all ways but one; the waist was bigger. His mind must have been all over the place as he would never choose to wear these jeans and although they weren't as close fitting as he liked and hung a little low on him, they weren't about to fall down, so he decided to roll with it. Besides, where he was going it might be a good idea to have on a bigger pair of jeans.

Hemsworth froze as he was fishing out the keys from his pocket. That was weird, where did that thought come from? Why would he feel like it was a good idea to have on jeans with a bigger waist size to go and talk to someone? Hemsworth grunted in determination and unlocked the door purposefully. He was done trying to think his way through this, he needed more answers and less theories. He made the short journey from his front door to his cadillac escalade, jumped into it and began to make his way across the city.

The ride across town was pretty quiet, the streets were clear and his journey there was pretty smooth which put him in a slightly better frame of mind. It felt a little ridiculous to take such a big vehicle when it was just him, maybe he should have taken the time to take one of his smaller cars. Then again, as much as it pained him to admit it, sometimes it made him feel in control and powerful to show off something so impressively big. Today must be one of those days.

The parking lot was quiet and there only seemed to be a couple of people about when he got to The Ranch. He managed to park the escalade with very little fuss, although as Evans would no doubt have pointed out that was probably because there were no other cars around for him to have to try and park around. It had taken him a while to get used to maneuvering something so large, but now he was almost completely used to it and kind of enjoyed the challenge. As he hopped out of the car, he noticed a member of staff that he recognised from The Ranch dragging a comically oversized sign out onto the forecourt and strode in quickly and confidently to help him out. As he approached the kid looked up with a start, before a big smile spread out across his face. He had the kind of genuine, open smile that meant that PR training or not, Hemsworth found it impossible not to grin back warmly.

"Oh, hello Mr Hemsworth."

"Hello there," he replied with a nod. Hemsworth leant down and grabbed the other side of the sign and looked back over to the kid. "How about you lead and I follow?" The kid nodded and the two of them maneuvered it toward the edge of the kerb, before placing it down gently. No wonder the kid had trouble with it, the sheer size and the weight of it meant that he would probably find it a challenge to move it, but only because it was so wide that it would be hard to centre the weight.

"Thanks." The kid said, still beaming.

"No problem, err..."

"Ken, it's Ken," he offered up quickly.

"Thanks, I'm pretty lousy with names." Hemsworth said, shifting his weight on the spot with the languid confidence of a cat.

"No problem, it must be difficult to remember talking with people in your line of work."

"I remember talking with you. It must have been a couple of months back, you asked me for some workout tips. I pointed you to a website and Ruffalo pulled out that magazine which had my Thor workout plan in and gave it to you."

"Yeah, that's right!" Ken said in surprise. "He got a pen and signed it right over your face on the cover..." Hemsworth nodded and shrugged.

"He thinks he's pretty funny. How are the workouts going? Looks like you're filling out that shirt some more."

"Do you think so?" Ken said, his smile becoming a little more awkward, as he puffed out his chest.

"Definitely."

"Thanks! I took a look at that website you pointed me to, found a workout partner here at the restaurant and the guys in the kitchen started to make some high protein food for me. I hoped that maybe my work was paying off, but I didn't think it was that noticable..."

"We're always our own hardest critics and slowest to notice our progress. Keep putting in the work and I'm sure that you'll be bigger than me in no time." As the words came out of his mouth, Hemsworth realised he didn't like the idea of anyone getting bigger than him. Maybe rather than cutting back on the workouts and relaxing now that shooting was done, he'd have to put more effort into getting bigger.

"I find it so hard to believe that you didn't notice your progress. I mean, you look so..." Ken trailed off the sentence and his eyes turned down as he began to blush.

"Thank you." Hemsworth said quickly to try and spare the kid any more embarrassment. Because Ken seemed like such an open book and so earnest, he felt geuinely flattered. Perhaps because he wanted to change the subject, Ken was the one to advance the conversation.

"Is there anything I can help you with today, Mr Hemsworth? To be honest, now isn't a great time to get food as we're usually dead when we first open and the kitchen has only just started prepping."

"I wasn't after anything to eat, actually I needed some information."

"Oh OK, I'll do what I can to help." Hemsworth found himself grinning again warmly at the kid.

"I came down here last night for a meal and I needed to know something about it." Hemsworth said carefully, trying to be as vague as possible as he went fishing.

"I heard that you were here yesterday with Mr Evans." Hemsworth had to fight the urge to ask him exactly what else he had heard about last night. Ken seemed like one of the good ones, but he had no desire to put the idea of a scandal into his head. "What did you need to know?"

"Something weird happened..."

"I hope it was nothing to do with the food." Ken said. "Or the staff."

"No, well, I mean, it's a little bit delicate." Hemsworth realised that he was dancing along the line of sounding guilty and that Ken knew nothing. "I don't suppose there is anyone working now that was here last night?"

"Oh of course, would you like to come inside and I'll see if I can come up with a solution for you." Ken already started to take quick, determined steps back into The Ranch, leaving Hemsworth to follow his lead once more with his long, effortless strides. Ken lead him to the bar and turned back to face him. "If you'd like to wait here, I think I have a couple of ideas on how to get the information that you need. I shouldn't be too long."

"Thank you." Ken began to scurry off but suddenly turned without missing a beat and started to walk backward.

"Can I get you a drink while you wait?"

"No, I'm fine. Thanks." Ken twisted around again and jogged slowly through the saloon doors to the back of house area, leaving Hemsworth alone with his thoughts.

With the bright sunlight pouring in through the broad glass front and the deserted floor with many chairs still stacked off to the side, the place felt a lot different from what he remembered of the previous night but he still felt a sense of ill ease. He really hoped that Ken or someone here could help to fill in the blanks. He hadn't been drinking that much and he clearly hadn't had a blackout, but even if there was a medical reason for forgetting part of the night that wouldn't explain Evans' unusual behaviour. As time began to pass, his thoughts bounced around from the previous evening, to the last few scenes that he had been filming and the pressure and experiences of the last six months. All the while it felt like something was moving around underneath, hard to see or hold onto but ready to break the surface at any moment and although he didn't know what that entailed, the thought scared Hemsworth. He was suddenly jolted out of his thoughts by the sound of footsteps walking toward him from somewhere to the side and he turned to see...

Hemsworth turned and saw a lithe man in a tailored suit slowly walk up to him. He looked vaguely familiar and he was fairly sure that he had seen him before, but had they not been in The Ranch then he wouldn't have placed him there. He had a poised, controlled way of walking and there seemed to be an air of stillness about him. As he got closer, Hemsworth could feel his worries start to slowly slip away, or at least somehow become more muted.

"Hello Mr Hemsworth. Ken thought that I may be able to be of some assistance to you?" The man offered his hand and the moment that Hemsworth took it, he felt instantly much more at ease. His handshake was warm and firm and he just knew that this was the man to talk to help clear things up.

"Oh, yes, although to be honest I feel a little foolish now." The man slowly took his hand from Hemsworth's and it felt like strands of toffee being being pulled slowly and stickily apart. It felt warm, sweet and inviting and he missed it already.

"Not at all." The man said waving his hand as if to dismiss his concerns. "Ken said that you seemed worried about events last night and if there's anything I can do to help, it would be my pleasure." Hemsworth couldn't help but notice how rich and dark his brown eyes were, the colour of a decadent chcolate mousse that he could just sink into. He could feel his stomach gurgle and his hand instinctively went to his midirff to give it a light rub. A moment passed before he realised that he should probably say something.

"Err, yes. Well to be honest, I'm having trouble remembering exactly what happened. I have a large blank spot where a lot of the night should be." The man cocked his head to the side and stared deeply into Hemsworth's eyes. His instinct was to tear his gaze away, but he fought to maintain eye contact. The man smiled thinly before dropping his gaze.

"I can see why that may be worrying, but you may be better served by seeing a medical professional."

"Yes you're probably right, but I want to know if anything potentially embarrassing happened. If I did something that could damage my reputation and it got out..."

"Ah yes, I see your dilemma." The man said nodding. "You may not have the luxury of time to piece together what happened."

"Exactly." Hemsworth said, glad that he didn't have to go into too much detail and that he was right to place his trust in this guy.

"Perhaps we should continue this discussion in my office." Hemsworth suddenly felt a knot in his gut. Why did they have to leave a public space to discuss what happened? What had he done? He felt a hand clamp down on his shoulder and the man motioned for him to walk through the saloon doors and he found himself nodding and walking slowly forward. There was a long corridor filled with clutter and the sounds that came from the side seemed to indicate that the kitchen was there, but the hand remained on his shoulder, guiding his every step forward. When he got to the door at the end of the corridor he opened it to find an immaculately put together office. Not everything had the look of being new, but it was methodically organised and sorted. The man moved around him and took a seat at the desk, before leaning back and looking up at Hemsworth, bringing the fingers of his hands together to make a steeple.

"Did... something bad happen?" Hemsworth asked, rubbing his hands together nervously.

"Oh no, not at all. I didn't mean to give you that impression." The man at the desk said, smiling gently. "I merely wished to respect your privacy, since we can't be too careful about who may be listening in." Hemsworth felt instantly relieved.

"Thank you." The man leaned forward and rested his elbows on the desk, glancing straight up at Hemsworth and looking into his eyes once more.

"Well, I didn't spend the entire night talking with you and Mr Evans but at a certain point the restaurant quietend down and we had no new bookings so I spent a fair amount of time with the two of you."

"What happened?" Hemsworth interjected impatiently. The man smiled thinly.

"Very little of any consequence. Much of the time I spent at your table involved just you talking to me, or more accurately talking at me," he said, causing Hemsworth to look away and blush. "You were very excited about finishing up your new movie, looking forward to the future and talking about possible projects that you were considering. Come to think of it," the man continued, drumming his fingers on the desk, "one of the few times that Mr Evans spoke was to point out that you were behaving a little erratically, I think he used the word 'manic'. Perhaps that may have something to do with your memory loss? Either way, he seemed very worried about you." Hemsworth winced and began to slowly remember parts of the exchange. He hadn't wanted to call Evans as he didn't want to worry him; turns out, he was probably the first person he should have called.

"Was that it? Was that all that happened?" The man leant back in the chair and nodded gently, relaxing into the space.

"All that happened of any note. Mr Evans wanted you to get a cab home, but you seemed to dismiss the idea out of hand. I think he found it a bit difficult to handle you, so he eventually decided to step back and intervene only when it was necessary. Then the two of you left and that was it." Looks like he owed Evans a thank you and an apology.

"Thank you, thank you so much for filling in the blanks." Hemsworth said, feeling the weight of his worry beginning to lift.

"No problem at all. I was glad to help." The man said, smiling warmly. Hemsworth turned to leave and reached toward the door knob to let himself out. "Congratulations on your new movie role by the way." Hemsworth stopped in his tracks and turned back to face the man.

"My new movie role?"

"Yes, you receieved a call during dinner. Well I say new movie role, really it's just a continuation of your last." Seeing the confused look on Hemsworth's face, the man continued. "You don't remember? I assumed that you would remember such a big event, or you would have had some kind of confirmation by now."

"What was it? What was the role?" Hemsworth asked, with a mix of excitement and dread.

"I only know what I heard and what you told me, I don't know if I am the right person to..."

"Please!" Hemsworth begged. "I can't call the studio and ask what it was that I've already agreed to do. Besides, I started to remember things after you told me about them. I'm sure if you start telling me, I'll fill in the blanks." The man took a moment, tapping his index finger against his lips. For Hemsworth, it felt like an eternity.

"Very well." He finally said. "The same studio that made your last film called and offered you another Thor film." Hemsworth felt his heart sink at the news. He wasn't all that keen to go back to the Marvel universe, at least not quite yet. He needed a new challenge and a new character to get his teeth into.

"Oh, I see..."

"You didn't seem all that interested at first last night either, but you managed to get some fairly major concessions from the studio."

"Did you find out what they were?" The man nodded.

"You were rather vocal on the phone and in explaining yourself afterward. You managed to negotiate a large salary increase, mainly to reflect your exercise and nutrition needs."

"OK..." That sounded a little strange, but more money was more money.

"One bone of contention was a prosthesis that you used in your last movie. You didn't want to have to use it again in the new one but the studio seemed keen for you to."

"Yeah, I think I could do without Lebowski Thor this time around. Did I talk them round?"

"You did indeed." Hemsworth felt relieved again. He didn't want to retread over old ground. "You convinced them that you would gain all the weight yourself." Hemsworth's mouth fell open.

"I did what?" The man put his hands up and raised his eyebrows.

"Mr Evans seemed surprised that they agreed as well. You did sound very passionate and you certainly convinced me." The man said with a smile. "You also said that the only way that you would agree to it is if you were to gain substantially more weight than your prosthesis suggested in the last movie." Hemsworth's eyes widened even further.

"I said that?" The man nodded.

"You didn't want to do the same thing over again. You threw some numbers around that I didn't quite catch, but you did spend a particularly animated period indicating the size of the stomach you wanted." The man pushed himself back from the desk and drew his hand up to just below his chest. He drew it outward and curved it down so that his 'belly' rounded out just before his knees before sharply moving it back to just above his crotch. Hemsworth was starting to remember, but he had no idea why he would push for that...

"I believe you sold it as a case study on size and masculinity, the contrast of the big and the vulnerable. It would also show that big men are multi-faceted and you would try and gain as much muscle to emphasise that too." Yes of course, it was a big commitment but it was so right and just the sort of challenge he needed. To truly understand what it meant to be fat he had to become fat. "You seemed to think the idea of a handsome, muscular, famous, lithe man becoming very large would be a revelation to the audience too. I believe the word you used was..."

"Revolutionary..." Hemsworth finished absent-mindedly.

"Yes!" The man said clicking his fingers. Of course it was! This wasn't about Chris Hemsworth or Thor getting hugely fat, it was about art! This could change the way that people looked at the cinema! "The offer I made last night still stands today. The Ranch's kitchen is always open to you to realise your full potential."
